description.narrative: The overall development objective would be to increase the efficiency of operations regarding financial management, budget formulation, and budget execution, and the transparency of public expenditure management at the central and municipal level through the implementation of an updated, functionally enhanced and expanded financial administration system (SIGFE).

provider-org.narrative: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development

condition.narrative: DIPRES establish a Coordination Unit to manage Project coordination
SUBDERE assign qualified and experience technical and fiduciary experts
SUBDERE enter into an agreement with 100 Municipalities prior to submitting withdrawal aplications in respect of expenditures forPart C of the Project

title.narrative: Number of institutions where time required to aggregate financial data for the central government is reduced from 30 to 8 days

comment.narrative: Partially achieved. Financial information for the central government institutions in SIGFE and SIGFE II, and the homologatedinstitutions is turned in within the first 15 days of each month. For institutions within the coverage of the central government(exceptthe Public Treasury), the closing period is the 8th working day of each month, and information is aggregated in SIGFE thenext working day.

title.narrative: 100 new municipalities are using a new financial administration sub-systems

comment.narrative: As of May 2014, 100 municipalities are operating SIFIM.

title.narrative: Time lag to produce information on aggregated municipal budget expenditures has been reduced from 180 to less than 30 days

actual.value: Information can now be obtained in 90 days.

comment.narrative: Partially achieved. With the implementation and entry into operation of the municipal aggregator (expected in 2015), it will bepossible to have information in less than 30 days.

title.narrative: Increase efficiency of public financial management Administration by upgrading and expanding the national financial administration system and using common standards at the central level

baseline.value: Aggregated information available only on demand

actual.value: SIGFE II is 100% developed. Currently, there are 84 insititutions using SIGFE II, representing a 49% of the goal ofimplementationin 173 institutions.

title.narrative: Batch interfaces between SIGFE and ChileCompras, BIP of MIDEPLAN and other selected systems have been replaced by full interoperability, YR 2-5.

target.value: Fully automated, real-time data exchange between SIGFE & ChileCompras, MIDEPLAN#s BIP and other selected systems

actual.value: Interoperability with SIGFE 2.0 was fully developed. However there are delays with putting interoperability with Chilecompras intooperation due to changes in the basline of the Public Market application (following the development of the functionality withSIGFE2.0. Similarly the business model underlying the BIP and the functionality needs to be revisited, as the Ministry of SocialDevelopment is in the process of creating a new version of the BIP application.

title.narrative: Increase effectiveness and transparency in public expenditure management on the municipal level by developing a Municipal FinancialInformation System.

baseline.value: Consolidated financial information at the municipal level available in 180 days

target.value: A Municipal Financial Information System, capable of aggregating the information of all 345 Municipalities is implemented, andinformation is available in 30 days.

actual.value: SIFIM has been implemented in the 100 targeted municipalities. In regards to the municipal aggregator, the hardware and softwarelicenses, and the municipal aggregator system are installed in the Subsecretariat's office. The Municipal Aggregator is expectedto enter into operation in January 2015.

title.narrative: Upgraded SIGFE used by the 90% of the CGE that presently use SIGFE. The remaining 10% of CGE that operate their own systems should generate fin. info. consistent with SIGFE financial info. requirement

baseline.value: Lack of reliable and timely financial information consolidated for the entire public sector

target.value: Fully integrated, online data transfer for 100% of Central government's financial information

actual.value: 84 institutions using SIGFE 2.0 in May 2014 (representing 49% of the institutions covered by SIGFE I). In regards to theinstitutions operating their own (homologous) systems, the Institute of Labor Security has been operating SIGFE 2.0 since 2011, andpositive viability studies have been carried out in the Ministry of Public Works and the Social Security Institute. There havealso been advances in the homogalation of the accounting conditions in the Public Treasury to SIGFE's rules and requirements.

title.narrative: SIAP implemented in DIPRES, including interoperability with SIGFE, YR 2-5.

baseline.value: Limited integration of SIAP with SIGFE

target.value: SIAP in operation producing integrated financial and budget information

actual.value: Following postponement of the project in 2012, authorities decided to reinitiate the project in 2014. It is hoped to carry out thebidding process in August 2014, and have the contract by the beginning of 2015.

title.narrative: Municipal Information System developed that is capable of aggregating the information of all 345 municipalities

target.value: A Municipal Financial Information System, capable of aggregating the information of all 345 Municipalities is implemented, andinformation is available in 30 days.

actual.value: SIFIM has been implemented in the 100 targeted municipalities. In regards to the municipal aggregator, the hardware and softwarelicenses, and the municipal aggregator system are installed in the Subsecretariat's office. The Municipal Aggregator is expectedto enter into operation in January 2015.

title.narrative: SIGFE's configuration processes have been automated, YR 2-5.
Establishment of a new administrative structure and processes to institutionalize SIGFE within DIPRES, YR1-5

target.value: Creation of the Information Technology Department

comment.narrative: Information Technology Division was created within DIPRES.

title.narrative: Increase effectiveness of financial management at the local level by implementing a system built on common standards

baseline.value: Several incongruent systems used for financial administration at municipal level

target.value: Financial information of at least 100 municipalities is included in the Municipal Financial Information System

actual.value: 100 municipalities operating within SIFIM as of May 2014.

title.narrative: Project implementation and coordination as well as the monitoring and evaluation of the implementation process, FY 1-5

baseline.value: The process of monitoring and evaluation of the project will take place with a low level of implementation

target.value: 4 information exchange workshops amongst entities which have implemented the new transactional module of SIGFE.

actual.value: All workshops were carried out within the SIGFE 2.0 Users' Committee

title.narrative: Increased processing capacity of transaction module from 95,000 to 200,000 financial transactions per day with a response time within 8 seconds at port

baseline.value: Transaction processing capacity of 95,000 per day

target.value: 200,000 transactions processed per day and response time less or equal to 8 seconds

actual.value: With the institutions currently using the system, only 5% of the CPU is being used. Given results of performance and scalabilitytests, it can be projected that the system meets the target.

comment.narrative: Achieved. In performance tests, 154 transactions were processed per minute (equivalent to 9,240 per hour).
